poem:
### The Question

I read the news today,
and felt my heart grow cold.
A mother cradles grief,
her loss a story told
by fire and metal sold
with British brand and blood,
complicity unfolds
in Gaza's mournful flood.

Where lions once roared, 
now silence cuts like steel.
Who will take the sword
and end this deadly deal?
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I call on Keir Starmer to suspend arms sales to Israel and end Britain’s complicity in the killing | Zarah Sultana Whenever I see the heart-wrenching aftermath of an Israeli airstrike in Gaza – a Palestinian mother cradling the lifeless body of her child; a refugee camp engulfed by fire – I ask myself the same question. Were British-made weapons used to inflict this horror? Almost certainly, the answer at times is “yes”. Raining down". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
